I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  2010  country  programming  mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for technical assistance 
(TA) in financial management. The PRC country partnership strategy for 2008–2010, under the 
“inclusive  growth  and  balanced  development”  pillar,  emphasizes  the  strengthening  of 
governance  in  public  resource  management  to  improve  central  and  provincial  government 
finances and help develop the poorer, western provinces.1 A TA fact-finding mission on 3–9 
May 2011 discussed in detail the objectives, scope, implementation arrangements, costs, and 
terms of reference of the TA with the Ministry of Finance (MOF). This report reflects ADB’s 
findings  and  the  understanding  reached  with  the  government  on  the  TA.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2  
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The PRC has developed rapidly in the last 30 years. Its economy grew by more than 9% 
yearly on average and became more decentralized, market based, and integrated with the world 
economy.  The  government  budget  and  financial  management  systems  are  increasingly 
important  in  such  core  functions  as  supporting  economic  growth  and  stability,  resource 
allocation for national goals, delivery of critical public services, and protection of the vulnerable 
in society. 
A.  Fiscal Policy for Emergency Management 
3.  The  PRC  is  among  the  countries  most  affected  by  natural  disasters.  There  are 
established fiscal policies for emergency management,3 but research and further improvements 
are  needed.  Current  emergency  management  objectives  and  interventions  emphasize 
immediate  disaster  response  and  post-disaster  restoration  and  reconstruction.  Too  little 
attention is placed on prevention through stronger infrastructure, institutions, and capacity. In 
addition, (i) emergency management activities and funding are fragmented among the different 
ministries  and  levels  of  government  and  are  ineffective;  (ii) fiscal  policy  instruments  for 
emergency management (expenditure, revenue, and transfer policy) are limited; (iii) budget 
management and monitoring of emergency funds are inadequate; (iv) laws and regulations 
governing fiscal policy for emergency management are incomplete; and (v) emergency-related 
asset use and compensation policy lack a clear legal and institutional basis. 
B.  Management of the Social Insurance Fund  
4.  While the social security system is complex with different schemes and inadequate 
coverage of the population, in particular the rural poor and migrants, the total amount of social 
insurance funds (SIFs) has expanded rapidly and reached an estimated CNY2 trillion at the end 
of 2010.4 But social insurance management and service delivery is devolved, fragmented, and 
largely municipality based. The Social Insurance Law was passed by the National People’s 
Congress  in  October 2010  and  took  effect  on  1  July  2011.  Its  implementation,  including

3  Emergency management, or disaster management, is the organization and management of resources, roles, and 
responsibilities for dealing with all aspects of emergencies, including preparedness, response, and rehabilitation.  
4  The social insurance system in the PRC comprises pension, health, unemployment, maternity, and work injury

2   
consequent revisions in regulations and guidelines, and the rapid growth of the SIF require 
better management at the various levels.  
 
5.  A nationwide budget for SIF was compiled for the first time in 2010 on a 3-year trial basis. 
Implementation  has,  however,  been  significantly  hampered  by  the  highly  decentralized 
administration of the SIF. Financial and accounting regulations for SIF, issued in 1999, demand 
revision. The management of individual accounts and investments is not transparent and varies 
widely and unevenly among the tiers of government. The SIF accounting system is cash based. 
Relationships between provincial and local level social insurance agencies need to be clarified; 
in  particular,  policy  making  functions  must  be  separated  from  account  management  and 
payment services. 
 
6.  SIFs are invested at the various levels of government with inadequate coordination. 
Investments are restricted to bank deposits and government bonds, which offer inadequate 
protection  against  inflation.  There  is  a  lack  a  consolidated  social  insurance  database  and 
well-developed  information  system  for  sharing  information  vertically  (between  levels  of 
government) and horizontally (between ministries) for better coordination of social insurance 
schemes 
C.  Development of the Local Government Bond Markets  
7.  Since 1995, the Budget Law has barred local governments from borrowing or issuing 
bonds without State Council approval. As a result, infrastructure investments are often funded 
with revenues from land leases and with indirect off-budget borrowings, through public utility 
companies,  special-purpose  vehicles,  and  urban  development  investment  corporations. 
Granting local governments direct access to the bond market promises significant benefits. 
Local governments will gain access to more resources for infrastructure development and be 
exposed in the process to market discipline and reporting requirements. Fiscal transparency 
and good governance will thereby strengthen. Expanding local government borrowing will also 
help deepen the financial markets.                                                                                                                     
D.  The Leading Accounting Talent Project 
8.  Progress in putting in place the institutional framework for accounting, auditing, and 
corporate financial reporting in the PRC has been impressive. But the financial management 
profession needs further strengthening. New accounting professionals lack practical exposure to 
applying latest accounting standards. In particular, few leading accountants have the high-
quality international qualifications and experience and the senior management skills needed to 
cope with the demands of an increasingly open and advanced economy. The PRC had about 10 
million accountants at the end of 2009; of these, only 2% were senior accountants. 
 
9.  In 2010, MOF developed a talent development plan for the accounting industry for 2010–
2020. It was the first long-term national development plan for accounting professionals. As 
called for in the plan, the government is sponsoring the Leading Accounting Talent Project 
(LATP)  in  order  to  develop  qualified  accountants  capable  of  meeting  the  challenges  of 
internationalization in accounting and reporting practices. MOF launched the LATP in 2005 to 
bring the total number of leading accountants in the PRC  to 2,000 by 2020. The training 
provided  under  the  plan  is  centered  on  applicable  accounting  and  auditing  standards, 
professional challenges and values, and international dimensions of accounting and auditing in 
the corporate setting, in the public sector, and in the academe. Since 2005, 700 candidates 
have been identified and trained under the LATP and 50 of those have graduated. At the same

3 
time, the demand for leading accountants has risen as the PRC economy has internationalized 
and confronted the effects of the international financial crisis. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The expected impact of the project is increased fiscal effectiveness in national and 
subnational governments, and its expected outcome is deepened financial management reform 
at both levels of government. ADB is currently implementing four TA projects related to fiscal 
policy and public finance reforms in the PRC.5 This TA will supplement the current TA programs 
by addressing a wider range of key public finance and financial management reform issues.  
 
11.  Related  interventions  by  other  development  partners  include  World  Bank  projects 
involving (i) advisory analytical work in pension reform and rural and urban social insurance; 
and (ii) infrastructure and institutional reforms for the development of the local government bond 
markets, in cooperation with the budget department of MOF.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The outputs of the TA will consist of the following: (i) a fiscal policy framework for 
emergency management, (ii) a study on the reform of SIF management, (iii) a study on the 
development of local government bond markets, and (iv) support for the LATP. The fiscal policy 
and bond market studies will be published as knowledge products in the form of policy and 
technical notes to guide researchers and senior policy and decision makers. 
 
13.  Output 1: Fiscal policy framework for emergency management. A holistic fiscal 
policy framework for emergency management based on good international practice will be 
developed. An overall report and sub-reports on the following key areas will be prepared:  
 
(i)  Infrastructure, institutions, and capacity building for emergency management. 
Research  will  deal  mainly  with  (a) the  distribution  of  emergency  management 
responsibilities  among ministries,  levels  of government,  and  agencies;  (b) early 
warning systems; (c) emergency storage and reserve systems; (d) technology for 
emergency management; and (e) capacity building. 
(ii)  Fiscal  policy  instruments  and  public  financial  management  systems  for 
emergency management. Research will pertain to (a) stable revenue mobilization; 
(b) budget  and  public  finance  management  procedures  (budget  preparation, 
execution,  monitoring,  procurement,  performance  management,  and  auditing); 
(c) expenditure  and  transfer  payment  policy;  and  (d) the  integration  and 
strengthening of the related laws and regulations.  
(iii)  Emergency-related  asset  use  and  compensation  policy.  The  policy  will  be 
grounded in clear legal and institutional arrangements.

14.  Output  2:  Study  on  the  reform  of  Social  Insurance  Fund  management.  Four 
interrelated key issues of SIF management reform under MOF will be studied in depth, in 
relation to international good practice: 
 
(i)  Strengthening  of  social  insurance  budget  management.  The  method  of 
compiling a consolidated budget for SIF will be improved, and relevant regulations 
and guidelines prepared. A consolidated budget will tighten fund supervision at the 
various levels of government and establish a sound basis for central government 
subsidies and efficient fund investments. A consolidated budget, once published, 
will also increase the transparency of SIF operations. 
(ii)  Revision of financial regulations. The management of individual accounts and 
investment  must  be  standardized  and  made  more  transparent.  Financial 
transactions must involve a wider range of banks which cover rural areas. Interest 
rates on deposits must be standardized and the SIF must move toward an accrual 
system  of  accounting.  Relationships  between  social  insurance  agencies  in  the 
provinces must be clarified.  
(iii)  Improvement of investment strategy and systems. The investment of social 
insurance funds must be coordinated and unified across government. A nationwide 
framework  for  investment,  including  risk  management,  financial  control  and 
supervision, and governance structures, and a wide variety of financial instruments 
must be developed. 
(iv)  Expansion  of  computerized  management  information  systems  (MISs).  A 
nationwide computerized administration system with greater vertical and horizontal 
connectivity will (a) allow the establishment of a social insurance database with 
information about beneficiary accounts at central, provincial, and county levels; 
(b) reduce the risk of fraud and overlapping benefits; (c) promote the coordination 
of social insurance schemes and increase the transparency of individual account 
management;  (d) provide  data  to  improve  the  monitoring  of  SIF  performance; 
(e) make it easier for the central government to supervise account management 
and investment; and (f) facilitate the portability of pension rights.  
 
15.  Output 3: Study on the development of local government bond markets. Operating 
mechanisms, institutions, and the transition to a nationwide system of local government bond 
markets will be studied. The research will be based on international good practice and the 
experience of different provinces in the PRC, and will include a survey of the literature on the 
local government bond markets in three developed countries. Five provinces, representing the 
various  geographic  regions  of  the  PRC  (eastern,  central,  southwestern,  northeast,  and 
northwestern), will be selected for an examination of the preconditions for the setting up of local 
government  bond markets  in  different  provinces.  A team  of treasury department  staff  and 
designated consultants will make field visits to consult with local financial bureaus and financial 
institutions. The case studies will support pilot bond issues by the provinces in line with the 
current agenda of the treasury department.  
 
16.  The research will expand recent studies led by the budget department of MOF on the 
fiscal concerns connected with the issue of local government bonds by paying closer attention 
to the related core responsibilities of the treasury department and local finance bureaus. Those 
core  responsibilities  include  investor  relations,  bond  structure  and  yield  curve,  debt 
management, risk management, market liquidity, primary and secondary market development, 
information disclosure, and rating.

5 
17.  Output 4: Support for the Leading Accounting Talent Project. A mid-term review of 
the LATP will be carried out and the overall framework for capacity building under that project 
will be revised. Research on two selected accounting management areas, i.e., internal control 
systems and financial and accounting methods for international acquisitions, will be conducted, 
based on case studies on selected companies. A model will be developed for the adoption of 
the internal control regulations and implementing guidelines that were issued in 2008 and 2010. 
The  case  studies  will  provide  benchmarks for the  proper  use  of  accounting  standards for 
international  acquisitions,  which  now  poses  a  major  challenge  to  state-owned  and  private 
enterprises in the PRC.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.4 million. At the government’s request, ADB 
will finance $1.2 million with a grant from its Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other 
sources) and the government will cover $0.2 million in local currency costs in kind, comprising 
office accommodation, counterpart staff, and other related services. Detailed cost estimates are 
in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The International Department of MOF will be the executing agency. Various other MOF 
departments will be the implementing agencies—the Department of Economic Construction for 
the  fiscal  policy  framework  for  emergency  management  (output 1);  the  Social  Security 
Department for the study on SIF management reform (output 2); the Treasury Department for 
the  study  on  local  government  bond  market  development  (output 3);  and  the  Accounting 
Regulatory  Department  for  support  for  the  LATP  (output 4).  A  team  of  four  international 
consultants (6 person-months) and 15 national experts (99 person-months) will be hired. The 
TA activities are expected to start in November 2011 and end in December 2013. 
 
20.  The  International  Department  of  MOF,  as  executing  agency,  will  supervise  the 
day-to-day work of the consultants, in consultation with the implementing agencies. The national 
consultants  will  be  hired  through  firms.  As  no  single  firm  can  be  expected  to  provide 
well-qualified consultants for the entire TA project, given the diversity of the outputs, the national 
consultants are to come from several firms. The firms will be recruited through quality- and 
cost-based selection at a quality–cost ratio of 80:20. If no suitable firms can provide the required 
national consultants, making quality-and cost-based selection inapplicable, the consultants may 
be  hired  individually,  subject  to  the  appropriate  ADB  approval  process.  The  international 
consultants will be hired individually. ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time) will be used in the hiring of all the TA consultants. The TA proceeds 
will be disbursed according to the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,200,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Public  Finance  and  Financial 
Management Reforms, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require a total of 105 person-months of consulting 
services (4 international consultants for a total of 6 person-months and 15 national consultants 
for a total of 99 person-months). The international consultants should each have a postgraduate 
degree and expertise gained from at least 15 years’ international experience in a field relevant 
to the assignment, including experience in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). The national 
consultants will form the working group for each output and prepare the research studies (the 
overall study report, sub-reports, and knowledge products), in cooperation with designated staff 
of the implementing agency and with advice from the international consultants. Each working 
group will be headed by a national team leader. The national consultants will take responsibility 
for arranging national and international workshops and international study tours.  
A.  Output 1: Fiscal Policy Framework for Emergency Management  
1.   Public Finance Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
2.  The international consultant should have substantial expertise and experience in public 
finance, particularly in (i) emergency management, (ii) general principles of taxation, (iii) public 
expenditure  and  budget  management,  and  (iv) financial  sector  development.  The  specific 
responsibilities of this specialist will be as follows: 
 
(i)  advising  the  national  specialists  on  theory,  good  international  practice,  and 
experience in fiscal policy for emergency management, and on a suitable way of 
adapting the lessons to the specific conditions in the PRC; and 
(ii)  advising on key research topics related to international trends in fiscal policy for 
emergency  management,  including  (a) objectives;  (b) infrastructure  and 
institutions;  (c) distribution  of  responsibilities  and  integration  of  emergency 
management functions; (d) management capacity; (e) risk transfer instruments in 
financial markets; (f) budget management; (g) fiscal policy instruments (revenue, 
expenditure,  and  transfers);  (h) legal  and  regulatory  infrastructure; 
(i) transparency of operations, and the monitoring and evaluation of emergency 
funds; (j) treasury management; and (k) asset use and compensation policy. 
2.  Public Finance Specialists (national, four specialists, 25 person-months) 
3.  The  specialists  will  each  have  a  postgraduate  degree  in  public  finance,  economic 
development, or other relevant field, and strong expertise and experience in public finance, 
particularly  in  (i) emergency  management,  (ii) general  principles  of  taxation,  (iii) public 
expenditure  and  budget  management,  and  (iv) financial  sector  development.  The  specific 
responsibilities of these specialists will be as follows: 
 
(i)  preparing  questionnaires,  carrying  out  field  surveys  and  collecting  data,  and 
consulting  stakeholders  on  current  practices  in  fiscal  policy  for  emergency 
management; 
(ii)  analyzing  and  assessing  the  current  design  of  fiscal  policy  for  emergency 
management in the PRC; 
(iii)  reviewing the national and international literature on theory, good international 
practice, experience, and lessons in fiscal policy for emergency management; 
(iv)  carrying out research into topics related to international trends in fiscal policy for 
emergency  management,  including  (a) objectives;  (b) infrastructure  and

Appendix 3  11 
institutional arrangements; (c) distribution of responsibilities and integration of 
emergency management functions; (d) management capacity; (e) risk transfer 
instruments  in  financial  markets;  (f) budget  management;  (g) fiscal  policy 
instruments  (revenue,  expenditure,  and  transfers);  (h) legal  and  regulatory 
infrastructure; (i) transparency of operations, and monitoring and evaluation of 
emergency funds; (j) treasury management; and (k) asset use and compensation 
policy; and 
(v)  identifying capacity-building needs in national and subnational government. 
B.  Output 2: Study on the Reform of Social Insurance Fund Management  
1.  Social Insurance Fund Management Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
4.  The international consultant should have substantial expertise and experience in public 
finance  and  fund  management,  particularly  in  (i) social  insurance  systems,  (ii) budget 
management, (iii) capital markets, (iv) asset management, and (v) the design of computerized 
management information systems (MISs). The specific responsibilities of this specialist will be 
as follows: 
 
(i)  advising on the fundamental theory of social insurance fund management; 
(ii)  advising on good international practice and experience in institutional design and 
management of social insurance funds, and on a suitable way of adapting the 
lessons to specific conditions in the PRC; and 
(iii)  advising on research topics related to international trends in social insurance 
fund management, such as (a) investment policies and strategies, including risk 
management, financial control and supervision, and governance; (b) monitoring 
and  supervision  of  individual  accounts  and  investment;  (c) fund  collection 
mechanisms  and  compilation  of  a  consolidated  national  budget  for  social 
insurance;  (d) financial  and  accounting  regulations;  (e) legal  and  regulatory 
infrastructure; (f) operating procedures for social insurance administration and 
account management; and (g) design of computerized MISs at the national and 
provincial levels. 
2.  Social Insurance Fund Management Specialists (national, three specialists, 
24 person-months) 
5.  The specialists will do in-depth research on four key elements of social insurance fund 
management reform—strengthening social insurance budget management, revising financial 
and  accounting  regulations,  improving  investment  strategy  and  systems,  and  expanding 
computerized MISs. The specialists will have extensive in-depth knowledge of the local industry 
and good contacts in various areas of social insurance and capital markets. The specialists 
should each have a postgraduate degree in economics, public finance, or a related field, and 
strong expertise and experience in public finance and fund management, particularly in (i) social 
insurance systems, (ii) budget management, (iii) capital markets, (iv) asset management, and 
(v) design of computerized MISs. The specific responsibilities of these specialists will be as 
follows: 
 
(i)  reviewing the national and international literature on theory, good international 
practice, experience, and lessons in social insurance fund management, under 
the guidance of the international specialist;

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(ii)  preparing  questionnaires,  carrying  out  field  surveys  and  collecting  data,  and 
consulting  stakeholders  in  selected  provinces  and  municipalities  on  current 
practices in key aspects of social insurance fund management; 
(iii)  analyzing and assessing the design of social insurance fund management in the 
PRC; 
(iv)  carrying out in-depth research in key areas of social insurance fund management, 
such  as  (a) investment  policies  and  strategies,  including  risk  management, 
financial control and supervision, and governance; (b) monitoring and supervision 
of  individual  accounts  and  investment;  (c) fund  collection  mechanisms  and 
compilation of a consolidated national budget for social insurance; (d) financial 
and accounting regulations; (e) legal and regulatory infrastructure; (f) operating 
procedures for social insurance administration and account management; and 
(g) design of computerized MISs at the national and provincial levels; and 
(v)  identifying capacity-building needs for social insurance fund management at the 
Ministry of Finance (MOF), provincial, and sub-provincial levels. 
C.  Output 3: Study on the Development of Local Government Bond Markets 
1.  Treasury  Management  and  Bond  Market  Specialist  (international, 
1 person-month) 
6.  The international consultant should have substantial expertise and experience in public 
finance, particularly in a variety of areas related to municipal finance and treasury management, 
including  local government  debt management and  bond market  development. The  specific 
responsibilities of this specialist will be follows: 
 
(i)  supporting the survey of the literature on local government debt management 
and bond market development in selected developed countries; 
(ii)  advising on the identification of a variety of provinces for a study of preconditions 
and measures for the setting up of local bond markets; 
(iii)  advising  the  national  specialists  on  theory,  good  international  practice,  and 
experience in establishing operating mechanisms and developing institutions for 
a nationwide local bond market system, and on a suitable way of adapting the 
lessons to specific conditions in the PRC; and 
(iv)  advising the national specialists on research topics related to international trends 
and  good  practice  in  local  government  debt  management  and  bond  market 
development, such as (a) investor relations; (b) bond structure and yield curve; 
(c) debt management; (d) risk management; (e) market liquidity; (f) introduction 
and promotion of primary and secondary markets; (g) information disclosure; and 
(h) rating. 
2.  Treasury Management and Bond Market Specialists (national, four specialists, 
24 person-months) 
7.  The specialists should each have a postgraduate degree in economics, finance, or a 
related field, and strong expertise and experience in public finance, particularly in a variety of 
areas related to municipal finance and treasury management, including local government debt 
management and bond market development. The specific responsibilities of these specialists 
will be as follows:

Appendix 3  13 
(i)  preparing a survey of the literature on local government debt management and 
bond market development in selected developed countries;            
(ii)  reviewing the national and international literature on theory, good international 
practice, experience, and lessons in local government debt management and 
bond market development, supported by the international specialist; 
(iii)  identifying preconditions and measures for the setting up of local bond markets in 
a variety of selected provinces; 
(iv)  carrying out research on key areas of local government debt management and 
bond market development, including (a) investor relations, (b) bond structure and 
yield  curve,  (c) debt  management,  (d) risk  management,  (e) introduction  and 
promotion of primary and secondary markets, (f) market liquidity, (g) information 
disclosure, and (h) rating; and 
(v)  preparing a road map for the design and implementation of a nationwide system 
of local government bond markets. 
D.    Output 4: Support for the Leading Accounting Talent Project 
1.  Accounting and Capacity-Building Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
8.  The  international  consultant  will  be  an  experienced  certified  public  accountant  or 
equivalent  with  extensive  theoretical  and  practical  knowledge  of  professional  accounting 
examination systems in developed and developing countries and familiarity with the application 
of best-practice training. The specialist should have substantial professional experience in and 
knowledge  of  accounting,  auditing,  and  financial  reporting  in  the  PRC.  The  specific 
responsibilities of this specialist will be as follows: 
 
(i)  advising the national specialists on good international practice and experience in 
capacity-building programs for leading accountants and on a suitable way of 
adapting the lessons to specific conditions in the PRC; 
(ii)  advising  the  national  specialists  on  the  review  and  analysis  of  the  Leading 
Accounting Talent Project (LATP), including its curricula and its examination and 
certification system; 
(iii)  advising  the  national  consultants  on  the  revision  and  improvement  of  the 
capacity-building  framework  for  the  LATP  in  line  with  the  increasing 
internationalization  of  the  PRC  economy,  experience  from  the  international 
financial crisis, and international standards and best practices; and 
(iv)  developing  a medium- to  long-term  plan for  building  the  capacity  of leading 
accountants,  including  professional  development  goals  and  administrative 
structures and systems.  
2.  Accounting  and  Capacity-Building  Specialists  (national,  two  specialists, 
10 person-months) 
9.  The specialists will prepare a midterm review of the LATP and revisions in the overall 
capacity-building framework. The specialists will be experienced members of the Institute of 
Certified Public Accountants (ICPA) or have strong theoretical and practical knowledge of PRC 
accountancy  training  and  examination  arrangements.  The  specific  responsibilities  of  these 
specialists will be as follows: 
 
(i)  conducting research on the status of leading accountants within the accountancy 
profession in the PRC, and identifying short- and long-term development goals;

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
(ii)  reviewing and analyzing, in cooperation with MOF and the national accounting 
institutes, the examination and certification system of the LATP, and preparing a 
revised capacity-building framework in line with international standards and best 
practices; 
(iii)  doing  research  on  (a) international  benchmarks  for  leading  accountant 
examination  requirements;  (b) leading  accounting  examination  systems  in 
countries with well-established accountancy professions; (c) international trends 
in professional examination systems and the application of existing and emerging 
technologies (the analysis should extend beyond accountancy to other relevant 
professions and specialties); and (d) articles in the professional and academic 
literature  concerning  professional  examination  systems,  particularly  regarding 
examinations for leading accountants; 
(iv)  preparing options for the updating of the leading accountant examination system 
in the PRC, in line with good international practice;  
(v)  developing a medium- to long-term plan for the development and training of 
leading  accountants,  including  professional  development  goals  and 
administrative structures and systems; and 
(vi)  reviewing and improving core training material. 
  3.  Accounting Specialists (national, two specialists, 16 person-months) 
10.  The specialists will carry out research on two key accounting management areas in the 
PRC: (i) internal control systems, and (ii) accounting methods for international acquisitions. The 
specialists will work closely together with policymakers and other country stakeholders. The 
specific responsibilities of these specialists will be as follows: 
 
(i)  carrying out field visits and preparing case studies on current practices in internal 
control  systems  and  financial  and  accounting  methods  for  international 
acquisitions in selected enterprises;  
(ii)  on the basis of the findings from the case studies, developing a model for the 
adoption of recent regulations and implementing guidelines on internal control 
systems in the corporate sector; 
(iii)  on the basis of the findings from the case studies, developing benchmarks and 
guidelines  for  the  proper  application  of  financial  strategy  and  accounting 
standards for international acquisitions; and 
(iv)  carrying  out  a  diagnostic  review  of  relevant  rules  and  standards,  their 
establishment, and compliance record, with the International Financial Reporting 
Standards and International Standards on Auditing as benchmarks. 
E.  Reporting Requirements 
11.  The international consultants and national team leaders will report to the executing 
agency, the designated implementing agency, and the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The 
national team leader for each output will be responsible for delivering the overall report, with 
appropriate contributions from the international and the other national specialists. Each national 
team leader will submit (i) an inception report 1 month after the start of services, (ii) an interim 
report 2–5 months after the start of the TA, (iii) a draft final report 4 weeks before the end of the 
contract, and (iv) a final report within 2 weeks after comments are received from the executing 
and implementing agencies and ADB. The reports will be prepared in both Chinese and English. 
Each  international  consultant  will  submit  a  brief  inception  report  1 week  after  the  start  of

services, a draft final report 4 weeks before the end of the contract, and a final report within 
2 weeks after comments are received from the executing and implementing agencies and ADB.
